section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written by Jean Marzollo and photographed by Nancy Sheehan
section-block.rac_book_summary: When children grow, they learn to do more and more things by themselves. In this book, we see what babies can do. We see how we keep learning as we grow.

section-block.rac_copyright_line: 978-1-338-65526-1. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. How Kids Grow by Jean Marzollo, photographs by Nancy Sheehan. Text copyright © 1998 by Jean Marzollo. Photographs copyright © 1998 by Nancy Sheehan. Published by Scholastic Inc. Clifford the Big Red DogTM illustration copyright © The Norman Bridwell Trust.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 3: Growing Up

section-block.rac_body-text: Ask children: What new things have you learned to do? Were they hard to do at first? How did you learn to do them?
Invite children to dance to the PreK On My Way™ theme music to build excitement for learning about how kids grow.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we’re going to read How Kids Grow. This book was written by Jean Marzollo and photographed by Nancy Sheehan.
Scout the Squirrel enjoys books, especially informational ones. He likes to learn new things.
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read. Ready?
What can babies do?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What happens to babies as they grow? Look at the photos on this page. How are the children different from each other? Which photos show children who are younger than you? Which children are older than you?
How old is James? What is he already able to do?
What is James’s mother doing? Let’s pretend to be her and say, “I love to cuddle my baby!”
Which of these girls is a baby? What can Brittany do? A skill is something you practice until you can do it well. What skills does Brittany have?
What is Mark doing? Can a little baby do that? Use a sentence to describe Mark’s skill.
Let’s answer these questions about what makes you special.
What is your name?
When were you born?
How old are you now?
How would you introduce yourself to a new child in the class?
How do you think you have changed since you were a baby?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
What can babies do?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Then use Equity Sticks to pick 2–3 children to share.
Possible responses:
As children watch and listen, write and read aloud short sentences about what babies can do.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How could you help a baby sleep?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Three- to four-year-old children should be able to say their name and age, speak 250 to 500 words, answer simple questions, speak in sentences of five to six words, speak in complete sentences (by age four), speak clearly (although they may not be fully comprehensible until age four), and tell stories.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 3: Growing Up

section-block.rac_body-text: Start a discussion about what children have learned and how they have kept on trying until they learned how to do something new.

Explain that when we learn something new, like how to ride a tricycle or a bike, we need to keep trying and not give up. That is called persistence. Have children share their experience about persisting to learn something new.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to look for the Mind Builder persistence as we revisit the book How Kids Grow, written by Jean Marzollo and photographed by Nancy Sheehan.
Clifford loves reading about how persistence helps us to learn new things. Clifford doesn’t like to give up. He persists.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread parts of the book and look for the persistence Mind Builder in action.
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How do you think children learn to walk? What happens? Do they need to keep trying even after they fall down? (MB)
Do you think Noël used persistence to learn to ride a tricycle? What do you think she might learn to do next? (MB)
What else can Noël do? When you work on a puzzle, you solve a problem. How can persistence help you solve a problem? (MB)
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Revisit the solve problems Vocabulary Card.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How do you think persistence helped Alex learn how to string wooden beads? What do you think he might do with his string of beads? (MB)
How old is Annie? What can she do that you can’t do yet? What do you think was the hardest goal for Annie to reach? How did persistence help her? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Tape a line (about 6 feet long) on the floor and challenge children to walk along this “balance beam” to the other end. Then challenge them to walk backwards on the same line. Can they do it? Does it take persistence?
Have children draw a picture of this or something else that they could not do as babies but can do now. Invite volunteers to share their drawings in an author’s chair.
Have children explain in complete sentences what they were unable to do before but are able to do now. Then ask them how persistence helped them learn to do these things.
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about growing up and acquiring new skills.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: To encourage and support persistence in problem solving, provide activities such as puzzles and math games with more than one way to a solution. Resist the urge to fix problems for children and encourage children to keep trying. Remind them that learning is a part of growing, and that we all must persist in order to learn. (Reed and Young, 2017).

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 3: Growing Up

section-block.rac_body-text: Discuss with children that all living things grow and change—plants and animals and people. Ask children to describe how different animals grow and change.
Have children act out different stages in a child’s growth: holding someone’s fingers, crawling, drinking from a cup, walking up stairs, and cleaning up.

section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show the How Kids Grow book cover.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread the book How Kids Grow. This book was written by Jean Marzollo and photographed by Nancy Sheehan.
Scout loves How Kids Grow because he likes all the photos.
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read. Ready?
What are some things that we learn to do by practicing?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 3 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How old is Adeline? What can she do with her hands? How does she feed herself? How do babies learn to get from one place to another before they can walk? Do you ever crawl to get somewhere?
Steven is learning to do two things that rhyme. Can you name them? What else is he learning? Can you show me how to wave bye-bye? When do we do it?
What can Hanna do now? What do you think she did before she learned to drink from a cup?
How old is Alex? What can Alex do? Can you jump off the ground with both feet? Let’s practice it together.
How old is Welby? What can he do? Which activities did Welby have to practice to learn to do?
What game is Annie playing? What games do you like to play? How did you learn the rules for playing your favorite games?
How old is Adrienne? How is her smile different from a little baby’s smile? What has she done that took practice and persistence?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
What are some things that we learn to do by practicing?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then use Equity Sticks to pick 2–3 children to share.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: We learn to ride a bike.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you work together to write about how we learn to do something new.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How will you learn to write your name?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Three- to four-year-olds should be able to name familiar colors, understand same and different, compare sizes, count, sort objects by shape and color, complete age-appropriate puzzles, identify common objects and pictures, follow three-part commands, remember parts of a story, and understand times of day (e.g., morning and night).

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 3: Growing Up

section-block.rac_body-text: Lead children in a discussion about what they have learned this year. What thing was most exciting? Most fun? What was your favorite story? Your favorite informational book?
Have children act out something they learned in school this year. Create prompts based on the poster summaries to help children recall some activities they shared.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read What We Have Learned. It is a poster that has informational text.
Scout loves informational posters. This one helps him remember what he has learned.
Both How Kids Grow and What We Have Learned show us how we learn and change as we grow. Let’s see if we can find some ways the two texts are the same.
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show How Kids Grow book cover.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about how it connects to this week’s concept question:
How have we changed?
section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Big Idea
section.rac_body-text: Invite children to talk about the pictures on the Big Chart. Then read the related text on the back. Use these prompts for discussion.
Use Equity Sticks to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_d-hed_prompt: What We Have Learned; How Kids Grow
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: We all start life as babies. Then we grow and get older. What kinds of things do we learn along the way to becoming adults?
section.rac_d-hed_prompt: What We Have Learned; Let’s Investigate; How Kids Grow,
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: We learned about how things go. How do wheels help a bus or a bike go?
section.rac_d-hed_prompt: What We Have Learned; Discover Animals; How Kids Grow, page 13
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What did you discover about animals? How do we take care of our pets? Why do you think Steven likes to pet his dog?
section.rac_d-hed_prompt: What We Have Learned; Let’s Create; How Kids Grow, page 14
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How can we make art that shows our feelings? What materials do you like to use to make art? How do you think Bobby’s drawings will change as he gets older?

section.rac_body-text: Remind children of the poster headings. What would they like to know more about? How might they get more information?
Provide a prompt about something children learned this year. Have children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Three- to four-year-olds should be able to walk up and down stairs; kick, throw, and catch a ball; climb; run; ride a tricycle; hop and stand on one foot for up to five seconds; walk forward and backward; bend over without falling; and help put on and remove clothing.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 3: Growing Up

section-block.rac_body-text: Invite children to act out caring for a tiny baby. How can they be a good older brother or sister to a baby? Have them pretend to give the baby a finger to hold and to cuddle the baby. Remind them to be careful to hold the baby’s head because very young babies can’t hold up their own heads. They have to grow bigger and stronger first. Can they sing the baby a song to fall asleep?

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell and reenact the book How Kids Grow. This book was written by Jean Marzollo and photographed by Nancy Sheehan.
This book is nonfiction. Nonfiction books tell us about things in our world that are real. Scout learns a lot from reading nonfiction.
This week we read about how we change as we grow. As I read the book one more time, I want you to think about this guiding question:
What will you be able to do when you’re five and six years old?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to pick children to actively participate in responding to the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How is Bobby’s mother keeping him safe? What clues tell you that Bobby is having fun? The book says that Bobby can point. Can you point to your nose and eyes? Can you point to the window? The clock? The creativity center?
What does Hanna like to do? Do you like to look at books? What are your favorite books? Let’s pretend that we’re reading a book. How do we turn the pages?
How old is Mark? What can he do? Let’s pretend to build a tower of blocks. Can you make it even taller? How high can you go? Show me how tall your tower is.

How old is Adrienne? What things can she do? Can you count to five? To ten? Can you count to five or ten in another language? Pretend you’re going to do a cartwheel. What would you do first? What do you do next?

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to turn and talk with a partner about the guiding question:
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What will you be able to do when you’re five and six years old?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then use Equity Sticks to pick 2–3 children to share.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: I’ll be able to read some books.
I’ll be able to write a story.
I’ll be able to ride a bicycle.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write about something they will be able to do when they’re older. Invite them to share their work.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What will you be able to do with a bicycle?
I will be able to r_____ (ride) a bicycle.
I will be able to ride a bicycle.
How could you help someone younger than you learn to ride a bicycle or a tricycle?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Ask volunteers to help teach the class to count to ten in their home language. If possible, write the words on chart paper or a word wall where children can see them. If the language uses a different alphabet, ask an adult in the community to write the words for you. Show children that everyone–including you–can keep learning new things.
